Instrument_Host.name: VENERA 9
Instrument_Host.description:
Venera 9 and 10 were a pair of identical spacecraft prepared for the June 1975 Venus launch opportunity. Venera 9 was the first mission to return pictures from the surface of Venus, and the first to go into orbit around another planet. The Venera 9 spacecraft comprised two parts, an orbiter and an attached descent craft and entry system. The orbiter will be described here. The orbiter mission was to act as a communications relay for the lander and to explore cloud layers and atmospheric parameters with instruments including a French 3500 angstrom UV photometer, a 4000-7000 angstrom photo-polarimeter, a 1.5 to 3 micron infrared spectrometer, and a 8 - 30 micron infrared radiometer. The orbiter also carried a camera system, magnetometer, energetic particle detectors, and charged particle traps.
The orbiter 4V bus was based on the M-71 design, and consisted of a 110 cm diameter central cylinder comprising the UDMH / nitrogen tetroxide tanks surrounded by a conical compartment with two solar panel wings and a 1.6 meter high gain parabolic antenna attached to the curved surface. A bell-shaped unit holding the KTDU-425A propulsion system was attached to the bottom of the cylinder, and mounted on top was a 2.4 meter sphere which held the descent vehicle. Around the base of the cylinder was a pressurized toroid 2.35 meters in diameter that held electronics and science instruments. Power was supplied by a pair of solar panel wings extending from opposite sides of the cylindrical body, each 1.25 x 2.1 meters in size, giving a total span of 6.7 meters. Spacecraft attitude control and knowledge were provided by a gimbaled engine nozzle, nitrogen cold gas jets, and gyroscopes, with solar sensors, Canopus star sensors, and an Earth sensor.
Communications were provided via the high gain antenna and six omnidirectional helical antennas, four for communication with Earth and two for the descent vehicle. The high gain antenna provided communication with Earth in the decimeter and centimeter wavelength bands. Command uplink was at 769 MHz through the helical antennas. A 16 MB magnetic tape system was used for data storage. A boom holding the magnetometer extended from one of the solar panels. Thermal control was achieved through use of louvers and a radiator.
At launch the Venera 9 spacecraft, including the descent vehicle, had a mass of 4936 kg. This included 1093 kg of propellant. The dry mass of the orbiter was 2283 kg. The nearly identical Venera 10 mission was launched six days later, on 14 June.
